server.name: Volatility
server.comment: Execute volatility with command and return tabular output. Incase where proper json output is not supported, scripts returns error. User should use raw command.

arguments.name: cmd
arguments.description: The volatility command/module you want to use

arguments.name: memdump
arguments.description: Path to memory dump file on the system being used

arguments.name: system
arguments.description: System with Volatility installed to be used for the analysis

arguments.name: profile
arguments.description: Volatility profile to use

server.name: SplunkEmailParser
server.comment:
Classify an incident created from an email originating from Splunk.
The mail type should be in plain text, and inline: table should be selected.
Parsing is done in the following manner -
type is the header sourcetype, severity is the mail importance level, 
the incident name is the mail subject and the systems are taken from host.

arguments.name: body
arguments.description: Contents (body) of the email

arguments.name: subject
arguments.description: Subject of the email

server.name: DefaultIncidentClassifier
server.comment: Classify an incident from mail.

arguments.name: splunkSender
arguments.description: Email address from which Splunk sends emails to our mail listener

arguments.name: nexposeSender
arguments.description: Email address from which Nexpose sends emails to our mail listener

arguments.name: defaultIncidentType
arguments.description: The incident type to be set in case the email is neither from Splunk nor Nexpose

arguments.name: minRiskScore
arguments.description: Argument passed as-is to NexposeEmailParser. See its documentation for details.

arguments.name: minVulnCount
arguments.description: Argument passed as-is to NexposeEmailParser. See its documentation for details.

arguments.name: sentinelOneSender
arguments.description: Email address from which sentinel one sends emails to our mail listener

arguments.name: sentinelOneIncidentType
arguments.description: Incident type to classify sentinel one events to

server.name: NexposeEmailParser
server.comment:
Parses nexpose report into a clear table that contain risk score and vulnerability count for each server,
And creates a new incident for each server.

arguments.name: entryID
arguments.description: ID of the entry containing the Nexpose report. If none is provided, the script will iterate and find a relevant entry.

arguments.name: minRiskScore
arguments.description: Minimal Risk Score an item in the report needs to reach in order to trigger an incident. Leave empty to trigger for any risk score.

arguments.name: minVulnCount
arguments.description: Minimal Vulnerability Count an item in the report needs to reach in order to trigger an incident. Leave empty to trigger for any count.

arguments.name: defaultNexposeSeverity
arguments.description: Severity to be set on triggered incidents

server.name: NexposeEmailParserForVuln
server.comment:
Parses nexpose report into a clear table that contain risk score and vulnerability count for each server,
And creates a new incident for each server.

arguments.name: report
arguments.description: Full XML contents of the Nexpose report. If not provided, it will be taken from the Incident Details.

server.name: NexposeVulnExtractor
server.comment: Parse a specific server nexpose response in to a table of vulnerabilities.

arguments.name: report
arguments.description: Full XML contents of the Nexpose report. If not provided, it will be taken from the Incident Details.

server.name: VolRunCmds
server.comment: Execute volatility with command and return tabular output. Incase where proper json output is not supported, scripts returns error. User should use raw command.

arguments.name: cmds
arguments.description: Comma-separated list of volatility commands/modules to run

arguments.name: memdump
arguments.description: Path to memory dump file on the system being used

arguments.name: system

arguments.name: profile
arguments.description: Volatility profile to use

server.name: CheckFiles
server.comment: Iterate on all file artifacts in the investigation and return details of positives

arguments.name: fileNames
arguments.description: If provided, checks only files whose names are in the list. The names should be comma-separated.

server.name: CheckSender
server.comment: For phishing incidents, check the sender of the email via Pipl search

server.name: StaticAnalyze
server.comment: For phishing incidents, iterate on all attachments and run PE dump on each

server.name: AnalyzeOSX
server.comment:
Get file and url reputation for osxcollector result.
 will use VirusTotal for Url checks, and IBM XForce for MD5 checks.
 maxchecks : for 
 system  : system name to run agent on.
 section : the type check that OSXCollector should run.

arguments.name: section
arguments.description: Ask OSXCollector for a specific section

arguments.name: timeout
arguments.description: Timeout to be passed to OSXCollector script

arguments.name: maxchecks
arguments.description: Maximum amount of files/urls to verify

arguments.name: system
arguments.description: OSX System to be used

arguments.description: Sensor to query

arguments.name: size
arguments.description: Size for the response

arguments.description: Size of time window, in days

server.name: LCFindDomain
server.comment: Using Lima Charlie, find which sensor saw access to given domain

arguments.name: domain
arguments.description: Domain to be found

server.name: CBSearch
server.comment: Search Carbon Black for process & binary information

arguments.description: "process" or "binary" according to the type of search you want to run

arguments.name: query
arguments.description: Query to be run - in Carbon Black syntax

arguments.name: rows
arguments.description: Number of rows to return. If omitted, default is as stated in the Carbon Black API documentation, currently 10.

arguments.name: start
arguments.description: Start at this row #. Allows pagination through large response. If omitted, default is as stated in the Carbon Black API documentation, currently 0.

server.comment: Example of using McAfee ESM (Nitro) with advanced filters

arguments.description: Query limit. If omitted, defaults to 100.

server.name: PagerDutyAssignOnCallUser
server.comment: By default assigns the first on-call user to an investigation (all incidents in the investigation will be owned by the on call user)

arguments.name: query
arguments.description: Filter user. E.g. query=dan will find the first on call user with the string "dan" in their name

server.comment: Send incident details to pagerduty (useful to include in playbooks)

server.comment: Use wildfire file analysis and parse result

arguments.name: md5
arguments.description: MD5 Hash to look up

arguments.name: hash
arguments.description: Hash to look up

server.name: WildfireUpload
server.comment:
Upload file to wildfire for analysis.
Example usage: !WildfireUpload upload=2@3

arguments.name: upload
arguments.description: ID of a war room entry containing a file to be uploaded to the WildFire service

server.name: PanoramaConfig
server.comment: Set panorama configuration

arguments.name: ruleName
arguments.description: Name for the rule to be configured

arguments.name: xpath
arguments.description: Usually not required as ruleName is sufficient. Direct XPath to the rule entry to be modified.

arguments.name: srcIP
arguments.description: Source IP address

arguments.name: dstIP
arguments.description: Destination IP address

arguments.name: negateSrc
arguments.description: Yes/No - whether to negate the source IP address (match all except the specified address)

arguments.name: negateDst
arguments.description: Yes/No - whether to negate the destination IP address (match all except the specified address)

arguments.name: action
arguments.description: Action for the rule

arguments.name: service
arguments.description: Service for the rule

arguments.name: disable
arguments.description: Yes/No - whether to disable the rule

arguments.name: application
arguments.description: Application for the rule

arguments.name: srcUser
arguments.description: Source user for the rule

arguments.name: from
arguments.description: "From" value for the rule

arguments.name: to
arguments.description: "To" value for the rule

arguments.name: disableServerResponseInspection
arguments.description: Value for the "disable-server-response-inspection" option

arguments.name: description
arguments.description: Rule description

server.name: PanoramaPcaps
server.comment: Get panorama pcaps

arguments.name: pcapType
arguments.description: Type of Packet Capture

arguments.name: from
arguments.description: "From" value for the rule

arguments.name: to
arguments.description: "To" value for the rule

arguments.name: serialNo
arguments.description: Serial number for the request. For further information, see the Panorama XML API Documentation.

arguments.name: searchTime
arguments.description: Search time for the request. For further information, see the Panorama XML API Documentation.

arguments.name: pcapID
arguments.description: ID of the Pcap for the request. For further information, see the Panorama XML API Documentation.

arguments.name: password
arguments.description: Password for Panorama.

server.name: PanoramaMove
server.comment: Move panorama rules

arguments.name: xpath
arguments.description: Usually not required as "src" is sufficient. Full XPath to the source rule to be moved.

arguments.name: src
arguments.description: Source value for the request. For further information, see the Panorama XML API Documentation.

arguments.name: where
arguments.description: Values for the "where" parameter include "before", "after", "top" or "bottom". For further information, see the Panorama XML API Documentation.

arguments.name: dst
arguments.description: Destination xpath to move the rule. For further information, see the Panorama XML API Documentation.

server.name: PanoramaCommit
server.comment: Commit configuration to panorama

server.name: RemoteExec

arguments.name: system
arguments.description: Name of system on which to run the command

arguments.name: cmd
arguments.description: Command to run

server.comment: Execute a command on a remote machine (without installing a D2 agent)

arguments.name: fileNames
arguments.description: If provided, checks only files whose names are in the list. The names should be comma-separated.

server.comment: Search for a binary on an endpoint using Carbon Black

server.name: CheckFilesWildfirePy

arguments.name: fileNames
arguments.description: If provided, checks only files whose names are in the list. The names should be comma-separated.

server.comment: Get reputation for attachments using wildfire and if the file is not known upload it to wildfire, wait 15 min and get reputation again

server.name: CheckIPs

arguments.name: data
arguments.description: Raw text from which to extract IP addresses using the appropriate regular expression. If omitted, will scan Incident Details instead.

server.comment: Get reputation for IPs in the incident or given raw text

server.name: CheckSenderDomainDistance

arguments.name: domain
arguments.description:
The domain to be measured against the domain in the sender's email address.
Usually the domain used by the company for email, e.g. acme.com when users are assigned jane@acme.com

server.comment: Get the string distance for the sender from our domain

server.name: CheckSenderPy

arguments.name: email
arguments.description: Email address to look up. If omitted, will instead extract with regular expression from Incident Details, where the phishing email should be provided.

server.comment: For phishing incidents, check the sender of the email via Pipl search

server.name: CheckURLs

arguments.name: data
arguments.description: Raw text from which to extract URLs using the appropriate regular expression. If omitted, will scan Incident Details instead.

server.comment: Check the URLs in the incident, or raw text provided as argument, for malicious URLs

server.name: ExchangeFindAndDelete

arguments.name: mailbox
arguments.description: Mailbox to be searched, e.g. dave@acme.com

arguments.name: subject
arguments.description: Only match mails containing this Subject

arguments.name: attachmentName
arguments.description: Only match mails containing an attachment with this name

arguments.name: sender
arguments.description: Only match mails from this sender (Email address)

server.comment: Search for the given mail details and in the given mailbox delete found emails

arguments.name: reason
arguments.description: Reason for closing the investigation

server.comment: Close an investigation

server.name: CSActors

arguments.name: q
arguments.description: Search all fields for the given data

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: Search based on actor name

arguments.name: description
arguments.description: Search based on description

arguments.name: minLastModifiedDate
arguments.description: Search range from modified date. Dates are formatted as YYYY-MM-DD.

arguments.name: maxLastModifiedDate
arguments.description: Search range to modified date. Dates are formatted as YYYY-MM-DD.

arguments.name: minLastActivityDate
arguments.description: Search range from activity date. Dates are formatted as YYYY-MM-DD.

arguments.name: maxLastActivityDate
arguments.description: Search range to activity date. Dates are formatted as YYYY-MM-DD.

arguments.name: origins
arguments.description: Search by origins - takes a comma-separated list

arguments.name: targetCountries
arguments.description: Search by target countries - takes a comma-separated list

arguments.name: targetIndustries
arguments.description: Search by target industries - takes a comma-separated list

arguments.name: motivations
arguments.description: Search by motivations - takes a comma-separated list

arguments.name: sort
arguments.description: Sort is field_name.order, field_name.order where order is either asc or desc.

arguments.name: offset
arguments.description: Which page of the results to retrieve. It is 0 based.

arguments.name: limit
arguments.description: Number of results for the page

server.comment: Query CrowdStrike actors based on given parameters. For fields like countries and industries, multiple values can be passed separated by ','.

server.name: CSIndicators

arguments.name: parameter
arguments.description:
Based on what parameter to search.
See CrowdStrike documentation for details.
Can be one of indicator, type, report, actor, malicious_confidence, published_date, last_updated, malware_family, kill_chain, labels, DomainType, EmailAddressType, IntelNews, IPAddressType, Malware, Status, Target, ThreatType, Vulnerability

arguments.name: filter
arguments.description: Can be either match, equal, gt(e), lt(e)

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: The value for the given parameter

arguments.name: sort
arguments.description: Sort by a field. Should be field_name.order where order is either asc or desc. Fields are indicator, type, report, actor, malicious_confidence, published_date, last_updated.

arguments.name: page
arguments.description: The page to retrieve - 1 based

arguments.name: pageSize
arguments.description: The size of the page to retrieve

server.comment: Query CrowdStrike indicators based on given parameters.

server.name: SendEmail
server.comment:
Send an email with the specified parameters.
Attachments are provided as a comma-separated list of entry IDs.
Example usage: !SendEmail subject="File from war room" body="Please see the attached file. --DBot" to=jane@acme.com cc=john@acme.com attachIDs=89@3,46@3

arguments.name: to
arguments.description: Email addresses for the 'to' field

arguments.name: cc
arguments.description: Email addresses for the 'cc' field

arguments.name: bcc
arguments.description: Email addresses for the 'bcc' field

arguments.name: subject
arguments.description: Subject for the email to be sent

arguments.name: body
arguments.description: The contents (body) of the email to be sent

arguments.name: attachIDs
arguments.description: A comma-separated list of IDs of war room entries that contain files. Used to attach files to the outgoing email. Example: attachIDs=15@8,19@8

server.name: CopyFileD2
server.comment:
Copy a file from an entry to the destination path on the specified system. This uses the dissolvable agent's HTTPS communication channel rather than scp or other out-of-band methods.
Example usage: !CopyFileD2 destpath=/home/sansforensics/collectedbinaries/inv8_suspiciousPE1.exe.evil entryid=21@8 system=Analyst1

arguments.name: system
arguments.description: System to which we want to copy the file

arguments.name: destpath
arguments.description: Full filesystem path and filename under which to save the file

arguments.name: entryid
arguments.description: ID of the war room entry containing the file to copy

server.name: ADGetUserGroups
server.comment: Use Active Directory to retrieve the groups in which the specified user is a member. The user can be specified by name, email or as an Active Directory Distinguished Name (DN).

arguments.name: dn
arguments.description: Active Directory Distinguished Name of the desired user

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: Name of the desired user

arguments.name: email
arguments.description: Email address of the desired user

arguments.name: attributes
arguments.description: Include these AD attributes of the resulting objects in addition to the default ones

server.name: ADGetUsersByEmail
server.comment: Use Active Directory to retrieve the user associated with the specified email address.

arguments.name: email
arguments.description: Email address by which to search

arguments.name: attributes
arguments.description: Include these AD attributes of the resulting objects in addition to the default ones

server.name: ADGetEmailForUser
server.comment: Use Active Directory to retrieve the email address associated with the specified user. The user can be specified by name, email or as an Active Directory Distinguished Name (DN).

arguments.name: dn
arguments.description: Active Directory Distinguished Name of the desired user

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: Name of the desired user

arguments.name: attributes
arguments.description: Include these AD attributes of the resulting objects in addition to the default ones

server.name: ADGetComputerGroups
server.comment: Use Active Directory to retrieve the groups in which the specified computer is a member. The member computer can be specified by name or by DN.

arguments.name: dn
arguments.description: Active Directory Distinguished Name for the desired computer

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: Name of the desired computer

arguments.name: attributes
arguments.description: Include these AD attributes of the resulting objects in addition to the default ones

server.name: ADUserLogonInfo
server.comment: Use Active Directory to retrieve detailed information about a user account. The user can be specified by name, email or as an Active Directory Distinguished Name (DN).

arguments.name: dn
arguments.description: Active Directory Distinguished Name for the desired user

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: Name of the desired user

arguments.name: email
arguments.description: Email address of the desired user

arguments.name: attributes
arguments.description: Include these AD attributes of the resulting objects in addition to the default ones

server.name: ADGetGroupComputers
server.comment:
Use Active Directory to retrieve the list of computers that are members of the specified group. Group must be given by its AD Distinguished Name. The "attributes" argument receives a comma-separated list of additional attributes you wish to be displayed in the results.
Example usage: !ADGetGroupComputers groupdn="CN=ImportantComputers,DC=demisto,DC=com" attributes=operatingsystem

arguments.name: groupdn
arguments.description: Active Directory Distinguished Name for the desired group

arguments.name: attributes
arguments.description: Include these AD attributes of the resulting objects in addition to the default ones

server.name: ADGetGroupUsers
server.comment:
Use Active Directory to retrieve the list of users who are members of the specified group. Group must be given by its AD Distinguished Name. The "attributes" argument receives a comma-separated list of additional attributes you wish to be displayed in the results.
Example usage: !ADGetGroupUsers groupdn="CN=Domain Admins,CN=Users,DC=demisto,DC=com" attributes=badPwdCount,memberOf

arguments.name: groupdn
arguments.description: Active Directory Distinguished Name for the desired group

arguments.name: attributes
arguments.description: Include these AD attributes of the resulting objects in addition to the default ones

server.name: ADListComputers
server.comment: Retrieve the list of Computer objects stored in Active Directory. Use the "attributes" argument to include specific attributes in the results.

arguments.name: attributes
arguments.description: Include these AD attributes of the resulting objects in addition to the default ones

server.name: ADListUsers
server.comment: Retrieve the list of User objects stored in Active Directory. Use the "attributes" argument to include specific attributes in the results.

arguments.name: attributes
arguments.description: Include these AD attributes of the resulting objects in addition to the default ones

server.name: ADListUsersEx
server.comment: Retrieve the list of User objects stored in Active Directory and include an extended list of attributes and information about each user. Use the "attributes" argument to include additional specific attributes in the results.

arguments.name: attributes
arguments.description: Include these AD attributes of the resulting objects in addition to the default ones

server.name: Strings
server.comment: Extract strings from a file with optional filter - similar to binutils strings command

arguments.name: entry
arguments.description: Entry ID of a file entry to retrieve strings from

arguments.name: chars
arguments.description: Number of consecutive characters to be considered a string - default is 4

arguments.name: size
arguments.description: Display first 'size' results - default is 1024

arguments.name: filter
arguments.description: Regex to filter the strings - compiled with ignore case

server.name: RegProbeBasic
server.comment: Perform a short probe of the specified system's registry - retrieve and display the values of a list of interesting keys

arguments.name: system
arguments.description: Name of the system to be queried

server.name: RegCollectValues
server.comment: Collect values for the given registry path from all Windows systems in this investigation.

arguments.name: regpath
arguments.description: The registry path of the key to query

server.name: RegPathReputationBasicLists
server.comment: Check the given registry path against a small blacklist and whitelist. If the key matches neither, returns an answer of 2 meaning "Unknown".

arguments.name: input
arguments.description: Registry path to be checked

server.name: TaniumDeployAction
server.comment: Execute an action, optionally with parameters, and filtering - based on an existing package. See https://kb.tanium.com/SOAP for more information

arguments.name: packageName
arguments.description: Specify the package name. e.g. !TaniumDeployAction packageName="Clean Stale Tanium Client Data"

arguments.name: packageID
arguments.description: Use the package ID instead of its name

arguments.name: parameters
arguments.description: Use parameters with the package. See https://kb.tanium.com/SOAP for more details

arguments.name: comment
arguments.description: Comment to be added to the action history in the Tanium server

server.name: TaniumAskQuestion
server.comment: Send a request for a formatted result of asaved question. To receive the most up to date data, run the same command twice. See https://kb.tanium.com/SOAP for more information

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: Retrieve the question by its name. E.g. !TaniumAskQuestion name="Running Services"

arguments.name: id
arguments.description: Retrieve the question by its ID.  To view ID in the Tanium console go to: Authoring -> Saved Questions tab. This shows you a list of Saved Questions. Click the edit button on a Saved Question and the ID will be shown in the lower left corner

arguments.name: timeout
arguments.description: Force Tanium to respond after x seconds (even if data was not collected fully by Tanium)

server.name: TaniumAskQuestionComplex
server.comment: TaniumAskQuestionComplex - same as the AskQuestion command with additional filtering prepared by the script (an XML subsection added to the request).

arguments.name: timeout
arguments.description: Force Tanium to respond after x seconds (even if data was not collected fully by Tanium)

server.name: ADIsUserMember
server.comment: Use Active Directory to check if the specified user is a member of the specified group. Returns simply yes/no. The user can be specified by name, email or as an Active Directory Distinguished Name (DN).

arguments.name: dn
arguments.description: Active Directory Distinguished Name of the desired user

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: Name of the desired user

arguments.name: email
arguments.description: Email address of the desired user

arguments.name: groupname
arguments.description: Name of the AD group to check

server.name: ConferIncidentDetails
server.comment: Display the incident details retrieved from Confer in a readable format

server.name: ConferSetSeverity
server.comment: Set incident severity according to indicators found in an confer alert

server.name: CuckooDetonateFile
server.comment: Detonate the file in Cuckoo sandbox.

arguments.name: entryID
arguments.description: ID of the entry containing the file to detonate.

server.name: CuckooGetReport
server.comment: Get the report for a completed analysis.

arguments.name: taskID
arguments.description: ID of the task in Cuckoo.

server.name: CuckooTaskStatus
server.comment: Check the current status of a task in Cuckoo sandbox.

arguments.name: taskID
arguments.description: ID of the task to check.

server.name: FPSetRule
server.comment: Adds (or updates existing) rule in Forcepoint Triton. Preserves order of rules and modifies policy in-place if a rule exists with the exact type and value.

arguments.name: policy
arguments.description: Policy/action assigned to the rule - "allow" or "deny" only.

arguments.name: type
arguments.description: The Triton rule type - "dest_domain", "dest_ip", "dest_host" or "url_regex"

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: The value to match for this rule (domain, regex, etc. depending on the type)

arguments.name: remoteaccessname
arguments.description: If the Forcepoint Triton instance is configured as a RemoteAccess integration instance  insert its name here. Replaces argument "tritonsystem".

arguments.name: tritonsystem
arguments.description: System name of the linux host on which Forcepoint Triton is installed. Only use if not working with Triton as a RemoteAccess integration instance  if so, use the "remoteaccessname" argument instead.

server.name: FPDeleteRule
server.comment: Deletes a rule in Forcepoint Triton.

arguments.name: type
arguments.description: The Triton rule type - "dest_domain", "dest_ip", "dest_host" or "url_regex"

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: The value to match for this rule (domain, regex, etc. depending on the type)

arguments.name: remoteaccessname
arguments.description: If the Forcepoint Triton instance is configured as a RemoteAccess integration instance  insert its name here. Replaces argument "tritonsystem".

arguments.name: tritonsystem
arguments.description: System name of the linux host on which Forcepoint Triton is installed. Only use if not working with Triton as a RemoteAccess integration instance  if so, use the "remoteaccessname" argument instead.

server.name: CBPApproveHash
server.comment: Approve/whitelist a hash in CBEP/Bit9.

arguments.name: hash
arguments.description: The hash value to approve.

server.name: CBPBanHash
server.comment: Ban/blacklist a hash in CBEP/Bit9.

arguments.name: hash
arguments.description: The hash value to ban.

server.name: CBPFindComputer
server.comment: Find a computer in CBEP/Bit9.

arguments.name: query
arguments.description: Only show computers matching this query. If omitted, displays all computers. Query is in CBEP/Bit9 syntax documented in https://developer.carbonblack.com/reference/enterprise-protection/7.2/rest-api/#query-condition - e.g. "name:*srv*"

server.name: CBPFindRule
server.comment: Find the rule state for a hash value in CBEP/Bit9.

arguments.name: hash
arguments.description: The hash value to check.

server.name: CBAlerts
server.comment: Get the list of Alerts from Carbon Black Enterprise Response. Supports the same arguments as the cb-alerts command.

server.name: CBWatchlists
server.comment: Display all watchlists and their details, queries, etc.

arguments.name: id
arguments.description: Display a specific watchlist by watchlist ID (numeric)

server.name: IncidentSet
server.comment: Modify incident info such as name, owner, type, etc.

arguments.name: owner
arguments.description: Incident owner - must be an existing user in the platform

arguments.name: playbook
arguments.description: Assigned new playbook name

arguments.name: stage
arguments.description: Incident stage - must be from a predefined list of stages

arguments.name: details
arguments.description: Incident details

arguments.name: severity
arguments.description: The severity to set. Can be "low","medium","high" or "critical".

arguments.name: type
arguments.description: Incident type

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: Incident name

arguments.name: updatePlaybookForType
arguments.description: Should we also update the playbook according to the new given type. Can be yes or no. Default is yes.

arguments.name: labels
arguments.description: Set and override the labels for the incident. Labels expected format is [{"labelName": "labelValue"}, {"labelName1": "labelValue1"}] (JSON).

arguments.name: addLabels
arguments.description: Add to the list of labels for the incident. Labels expected format is [{"labelName": "labelValue"}, {"labelName1": "labelValue1"}] (JSON).

server.name: SendURLDetailsByEmail
server.comment: Get all details about URL (reputation, number of ads, etc.) and send them via email

arguments.name: url
arguments.description: The URL to get details for. If not provided, will be taken from incident details.

arguments.name: subject
arguments.description: The subject of the email. If not provided will be the incident name.

arguments.name: recipient
arguments.description: The recipient of the email

server.name: SendEmailToManager
server.comment: Send an approval email to the manager of the employee with the given email allowing the manager to reply directly into the incident

arguments.name: email
arguments.description: The employee email. We will send an email to his manager. If not provided will be taken from incident label 'Email/from'

arguments.name: manager
arguments.description: The manager attribute in Active Directory. Default is 'manager'.

arguments.name: entitlement
arguments.description: If provided (any value), we will add an entitlement to the subject allowing manager to reply to war room

arguments.name: body
arguments.description: The contents of the email body. It's a template that can include $empName and $managerName which will be replaced with actual values.

arguments.name: request
arguments.description: The contents of the request from the manager. Will be added below the body. If none is provided, incident details will be taken.

server.name: URLExtract
server.comment: Extract URLs from the given text and place them both as output and in the context of a playbook

arguments.name: text
arguments.description: The text to extract URLs from

server.name: IPExtract
server.comment: Extract IPs from the given text and place them both as output and in the context of a playbook

arguments.name: text
arguments.description: The text to extract ip from

server.name: MD5Extract
server.comment: Extract md5s from the given text and place them both as output and in the context of a playbook

arguments.name: text
arguments.description: The text to extract md5 from

server.name: TextFromHTML
server.comment: Extract regular text from the given HTML

arguments.name: html
arguments.description: The HTML to strip tags from

server.name: PrintContext
server.comment: Pretty-print the contents of the playbook context

arguments.name: outputformat
arguments.description: Output format - table, json or markdown. If omitted, default is markdown.

server.name: IncidentToContext
server.comment: Inserts incident info and labels into context for use inside playbooks.

server.name: SlackSend
server.comment: Send messages to Slack teams

arguments.name: to
arguments.description: Send a Direct message by specifying a Slack user name

arguments.name: channel
arguments.description: Specify a Slack channel where the message will appear.

arguments.name: entry
arguments.description: Send a link to this entry in the War Room

arguments.name: group
arguments.description: Specify a private channel

arguments.name: message
arguments.description: Message contents to send.

server.name: EPOCheckLatestDAT
server.comment: Check latest version of the DAT AV signature update

server.name: EPODetermineRepository
server.comment: Helper script to pick the relevant repositories to operate on within the ePO Auditing playbook

server.name: EPORepoList
server.comment: List all configured instances of ePO integration.

server.name: EPORepositoryComplianceCheck
server.comment: Check a list of ePO servers to see if they are up to date.

arguments.name: requireddatversion
arguments.description: Numeric DAT version, e.g. "8260"

arguments.name: repostocheck
arguments.description: comma-separated ePO instance names

server.name: EPORetrieveCurrentDATVersion
server.comment: Retrieve DAT version currently installed in the given ePO server

arguments.name: repos
arguments.description: Send a Direct message by specifying a Slack user name

server.name: EPOUpdateEndpoints
server.comment: Trigger an ePO Client Task to update AV signatures for specific endpoint

arguments.name: endpoints
arguments.description: Names of endpoints to update

arguments.name: eposerver
arguments.description: ePO instance to use

arguments.name: retryAttempts
arguments.description: Number of times the server will attempt to send the task to the client. Defaults to 1.

arguments.name: retryIntervalInSeconds
arguments.description: Retry interval in seconds. Defaults to 30.

arguments.name: abortAfterMinutes
arguments.description: Maximum number of minutes before aborting all attempts. Defaults to 5.

arguments.name: stopAfterMinutes
arguments.description: Maximum duration in minutes the client task is allowed to run. Defaults to 20.

arguments.name: randomizationInterval
arguments.description: Duration in minutes over which to randomly spread task execution. Defaults to 0 (execute on all clients immediately).

server.name: EPOUpdateRepository
server.comment: Trigger a Server Task in specific ePO servers to pull latest signatures from update server

arguments.name: repos
arguments.description: List of ePO servers to update

arguments.name: memdump
arguments.description: Path to memory dump file on the system being used

arguments.name: pid
arguments.description: Process ID to pass to volatility malfind command

arguments.name: dumpdir
arguments.description: Path to directory in which to save dumped memory sections

agent.name: D2GetSystemLog
agent.comment: Copy a log file. Works on Windows and Unix (differently - take a peek at the script itself to see how).

arguments.name: logName
arguments.description: Name of the log to retrieve

agent.name: CommonD2
agent.comment: Common code that will be merged into each D2 agent script when it runs

agent.name: D2Exec
agent.comment: Execute the command and pack the output back to server

arguments.name: cmd
arguments.description: System command to execute

agent.name: VolRaw
agent.comment: Execute volatility with command and file as parameters and returns raw output from stdout.

arguments.name: cmd
arguments.description: Volatility command to run

arguments.name: file
arguments.description: Path of file to pass as argument to Volatility

agent.name: VolJson
agent.comment: Execute volatility with command and file as parameters and return output as json.

arguments.name: cmd
arguments.description: Volatility command to run

arguments.name: file
arguments.description: Path of file to pass as argument to Volatility

agent.name: D2PEDump
agent.comment: Execute PE Dump on a file that is under /tmp somewhere. Used internally by StaticAnalyze

arguments.name: file
arguments.description: Path to the PE file to analyze, relative to /tmp

agent.name: Osxcollector
agent.comment: Execute osxcollector on machine, can run ONLY on OSX

arguments.name: section
arguments.description: Ask OSXCollector for a specific section

arguments.name: timeout
arguments.description: Timeout for the OSXCollector execution to complete. If omitted, defaults to 10 minutes.

agent.name: ExchangeSearchMailbox
agent.comment: Search all mailboxes on an Exchange server and copy the results to a specified target mailbox. This script runs through the agent on a Windows machine, pulls and executes a  PowerShell script - which talks to the Exchange server.

arguments.name: query
arguments.description: Exchange query to match against emails

arguments.name: toMailbox
arguments.description: Destination mailbox

arguments.name: toFolder
arguments.description: Folder within destination mailbox in which to place matched emails

arguments.name: server
arguments.description: Hostname of the Exchange server

agent.name: ExchangeDeleteMail
agent.comment: Search all mailboxes on an Exchange server for a query and deletes all messages in which query is satisfied. This script runs through the agent on a Windows machine, pulls and executes a  PowerShell script - which talks to the Exchange server.

arguments.name: query
arguments.description: Exchange query to match against emails

arguments.name: server
arguments.description: Hostname of the Exchange server

agent.name: ExchangeAssignRole
agent.comment: Assign a 'Mailbox Import Export' management role to a user. This script runs through the agent on a Windows machine, pulls and executes a  PowerShell script - which talks to the Exchange server.

arguments.name: username
arguments.description: Username to whom to assign the role

arguments.name: role
arguments.description: Choose a different role to assign to the user. Default is 'Mailbox Import Export'.

arguments.name: server
arguments.description: Hostname of the Exchange server

agent.name: D2Drop
agent.comment:
Drop a file to a target system by providing its path on the server. Use CopyFileD2 instead in most cases.
This is a utility agent script to be used inside server scripts. See CopyFileD2 for an example.

arguments.name: destpath
arguments.description: Full filesystem path and filename under which to save the file

agent.name: D2RegQuery
agent.comment: Use the D2 agent to retrieve the value of the given registry key.

arguments.name: regpath
arguments.description: The registry path of the key to be queried

agent.name: D2Winpmem
agent.comment: Use the D2 agent to carry the winpmem binary to a system and return the memory dump file to the war room. This usually takes a while, depending on amount of RAM in the target system.

agent.name: D2Rekall
agent.comment: Use the D2 agent to execute Rekall on a system (usually a forensics workstation) and analyze a memory dump file located on that system.

arguments.name: file
arguments.description: Path to the memory dump file in the machine's filesystem.

arguments.name: format
arguments.description: Format argument for Rekall e.g. json or text.
